div.p: THE OLD MAID. A COMEDY In TWO ACTS, As it is PERFORMED at the THEATRE-ROYAL in DRURY-LANE.

l.hi: Tempus erit, quo tu, quae nunc excludis amantem,

div.p: LONDON: Printed for P. VAILLANT, facing Southampton-Street in the Strand. MDCCLXI.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p:
AS the OLD MAID is now adven
turing into the world, it would be proper to acquaint the mere English reader, that the subject of it, and part of the fable, were taken from a little piece, in one act, called, L'Etourderie, by Monsieur Fagan. but that the author of these scenes is sensible, how superfluous that information will be rendered by the assiduity of some people, who, no doubt, will make a notable discovery of this prodigious crime, and press it home with all the reproaches of plagiarism, pilfer
ing, borrowing, robbing, translating, &c. But while this writer can add any thing to the decent amusements of the public, he is willing to be abused for it, in what
ever manner the illiberal shall think fit.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: CLERIMONT, Mr. OBRIEN.
Capt. CAPE, Mr. KING.
Mr. HARLOW, Mr. KENNEDY.
Mr. HEARTWELL, Mr. PHILLIPS.
FOOTMAN, Mr. CASTLE.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Mrs. HARLOW, Miss HAUGHTON.
Miss HARLOW, Miss KENNEDY.
TRIFLE, Miss HIPPISLEY.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. HARLOW and Miss HARLOW.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: MY dear sister, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
But, my dear sister, let me tell you it is in vain; you can say no
thing that will have any effect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Not if you won't hear me—only hear me—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, I know you love to hear yourself talk, and so please yourself;—but I am resolved—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Your resolution may alter.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Upon a little consideration.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Upon no consideration.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
You don't know how that may be—recol
lect, sister, that you are no chicken—you are not now of the age that becomes giddiness and folly.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Age, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Do but hear me, sister—do but hear me—A person of your years—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: My years, sister!—Upon my word—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Nay, no offence, sister—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
But there is offence, ma'am:—I don't understand what you mean by it—always thwarting me with my years—my years, in
deed!
—when perhaps, ma'am, if I was to die of old age, some folks might have rea
son to look about them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
She feels it I see—oh! I delight in mor
tifying her— (aside)—sister, if I did not love you I am sure I should not talk to you in this manner—But how can you make so unkind a return now as to alarm me about myself?—in some sixteen or eighteen years after you, to be sure, I own I shall begin to think of making my will—How could you be so severe?—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Some sixteen or eighteen years, ma'am!—If you would own the truth, ma'am,—I be
lieve ma'am,—you would find, ma'am, that the disparity, ma'am, is not, so very great, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Well! I vow passion becomes you inordi
nately—It blends a few roses with the lillies of your cheek, and—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
And tho' you are married to my brother, ma'am, I would have you to know, ma'am, that you are not thereby any way authorised, ma'am, to take unbecoming liberties with his sister.—I am independent of my bro
ther, ma'am,—my fortune is in my own hands, ma'am, and ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Well! do you know now when your blood circulates a little, that I think you look mighty well?—But you was in the wrong not to marry at my age—sweet three and twenty!—you can't conceive what a deal of good it would have done your, tem
per and your spirits, if you had married early—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Insolent!—provoking—female malice—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: But to be waiting till it is almost too late in the day, and force one's self to say strange things;—with the tongue and heart at variance all the time—"I don't mind the hideous men"—"I am very happy as I am"—and all that time, my dear, dear sister—to be upon the tenter-hooks of expectation—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: I upon tenter-hooks!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: And to be at this work of four grapes, till one is turned of three and forty—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Three and forty, ma'am!—I desire, sister—I desire, ma'am—three and forty, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Nay—nay—nay—don't be angry—don't blame me—blame my husband; he is your
own brother, you know, and he knows your age—He told me so

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, I see your drift—but you need not give yourself those airs, ma'am—the men don't see with your eyes, ma'am—years, indeed!—Three and forty, truly!—I'll assure you—upon my word—hah! very fine!—But I see plainly, ma'am, what you are at—Mr. Clerimont, madam!—Mr. Clerimont, sister! that's what frets you—a young husband, ma'am—younger than your husband, ma'am—Mr. Clerimont, let me tell you, ma'am—

sp.speaker: TRIFLE.
sp.p: Oh! rare news, ma'am, charming news—we have got another letter—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: From whom?—from Mr. Clerimont?—where is it?

sp.speaker: TRIFLE.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am—from Mr. Clerimont, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Let me see it—let me see it—quick—quick—

body.p:
The honour of a letter from you has so filled my mind with joy and gratitude,
that I want words of force to reach but half my meaning. I can only say that you have revived a heart that was expiring for you, and now beats for you alone—

sp.p: There sister, mind that!—years indeed!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
I wish you joy, sister—I wish I had not gone to Ranelagh with her last week—Who could have thought that her faded beauties would have made such an impres
sion on him?

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Mind here again, sister.—

body.p: Ever since I had the good fortune of seeing you at Ranelagh, your idea has been ever present to me; and since you now give me leave, I shall, without delay, wait upon your brother, and whatever terms he prescribes, I shall readily subscribe to; for to be your slave is dearer to me than liberty. I have the honour to remain

closer.signed: The humblest of your admirers, CLERIMONT.

sp.p: There, sister!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Well! I wish you joy again—but re
member I tell you, take care what you do.—He is young, and of course giddy and in
constant.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: He is warm, passionate, and tender—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: But you don't know how long that may last—and here are you going to break off a very suitable match,—which all your friends liked and approved, a match with captain Cape, who to be sure—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Don't name captain Cape, I beseech you, don't name him—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Captain Cape, let me tell you, is not to be despised—He has acquired by his voy
ages to India a very pretty fortune—has a charming box of a house upon Hackney-Marsh,—and is of an age every way suit
able to you.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
There again now!—age! age! age! for ever!—years—years—my years!—But I tell you once for all, Mr. Clerimont does not see with your eyes—I am deter
mined to hear no more of captain Cape—Odious Hackney-Marsh!—ah! sister, you would be glad to see me married in a middling way—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
I, sister!—I am sure nobody will re
joice more at your preferment—I am re
solved never to visit her if Mr. Clerimont marries her—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Well! well! I tell you, Mr. Clerimont has won my heart—young—handsome—rich—town house, country house—equi
page—To him, and only him, will I sur
render myself—Three and forty, indeed!—ha! ha!—you see, my dear, dear sister, that these features are still regular and blooming;—that the love-darting eye has not quite forsook me; and that I have made a conquest which your boasted youth might be vain of—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, I beg your pardon if I have taken too much liberty for your good—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
I humbly thank you for your advice, my sweet dear, friendly sister—But don't envy me, I beg you won't;—don't fret your
self; you can't conceive what a deal of good a serenity of mind will do your health—I'll go and write an answer directly to this charming, charming letter—sister—yours—I shall be glad to see you, sister, at my house in Hill-street, when I am Mrs. Clerimont—and remember what I tell you—that some faces retain their bloom and beauty longer than you imagine—my dear sister—Come, Trifle—let me fly this moment—Sister, your servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Your servant, my dear!—well!—I am determined to lead the gayest life in nature, if she marries Clerimont.—I'll have a new equipage, that's one thing—and I'll have greater routs than her, that's another—Po
sitively, I must outshine her there—and I'll keep up a polite enmity with her—go and see her, may be once or twice in a winter—"Ma'am, I am really so hurried with such a number of acquaintances, that I can't pos
sibly find time"—And then to provoke her, "I wish you joy, sister, I hear you are breeding"—ha! ha!—that will so mortify her—"I wish it may be a boy, sister"—ha! ha!—and then when her husband be
gins to despise her, Really, sister, I pity you—had you taken my advice, and mar
ried the India captain—your case is a com
passionate one—Compassion is so inso
lent when a body feels none at all—ha! ha!—it is the finest way of insulting—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: So, my dear; how are my sister's affairs going on?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Why, my dear, she has had another letter from Mr. Clerimont—did you ever hear of such an odd unaccountable thing patched up in a hurry here?

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Why it is sudden, to be sure—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Upon my word, I think you had better advise her not to break off with captain Cape—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: No—not I—I wish she may be married to one or other of them—for her temper is really grown so very sour, and there is such eternal wrangling between ye both, that I wish to see her in her own house, for the peace and quiet of mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Do you know this Mr. Clerimont?

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: No; but I have heard of the family—There is a very fine fortune—I wish he may hold his intention.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Why, I doubt it vastly—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: And truly so do I—for between ourselves, I see no charms in my sister—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
For my part I can't comprehend it—how she could strike his fancy, is to me the most astonishing thing—After this, I shall be sur
prised at nothing—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Well! strange things do happen;—so she is but married out of the way, I am satisfied—an old maid in a house is the de
vil—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Clerimont, Sir, to wait on you—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Shew him in (Exit Servant)—how comes this visit, pray?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: My sister wrote to him to explain himself to you—Well! it is mighty odd—but I'll leave you to yourselves. The man must be an ideot to think of her—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, I am glad to have this pleasure.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: I presume, Sir, you are no stranger to the business that occasions this visit.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, the honour you do me and my family—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, to be allied to your family by so tender a tie as a marriage with your sister, will at once reflect a credit upon me, and conduce to my happiness in the most essential point—The lady charmed me at the very first sight.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW
sp.p: The devil she did!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: The sensibility of her countenance, the elegance of her figure, the sweetness of her manner—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, you are pleased to—compliment!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Compliment!—not in the least, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: The sweetness of my sister's manner (aside) ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
The first time I saw her was a few nights ago at Ranelagh—Though there was a crowd of beauties in the room, thronging and pressing all around, yet she shone amongst them all with superior lustre—She was walk
ing arm in arm with another lady—no op
portunity offered for me to form an acquain
tance amidst the hurry and bustle of the place, but I enquired their names as they were going into their chariot—and learned they were Mrs. and Miss HARLOW. From that moment she won my heart, and at one glance I became the willing captive of her beauty—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
A very candid declaration, Sir!—how can this be? The bloom has been off the peach any time these fifteen years, to my
knowlege— (aside)—You see my sister with a favourable eye, Sir.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
A favourable eye!—He must greatly want discernment, who has not a quick per
ception of her merit.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: You do her a great deal of honour—but this affair—is it not somewhat sudden, Sir?—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
I grant it—you may indeed be surprised at it, Sir; nor should I have been hardy enough to make any overtures to you,—at least yet a while,—if she herself had not condescended to listen to my passion, and au
thorised me under her own fair hand to ap
ply to her brother for his consent—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
I shall be very ready, Sir, to give my ap
probation to my sister's happiness—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
No doubt you will—but let me not cherish an unavailing flame, a flame that al
ready lights up all my tenderest passions.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
To you, Sir, there can be no exception—I am not altogether a stranger to your fa
mily and fortune—His language is warm, considering my sister's age—but I won't hurt her preferment— (aside)—you will pardon me, Sir, one thing—you are very young—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Sir,—I am almost three and twenty.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: But have you consulted your friends?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
I have—my uncle, Mr. Heartwell, who proposes to leave me a very handsome addi
tion to my fortune, which is considerable al
ready—He, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Well! Sir, if he has no objection, I can have none—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
He has none, Sir; he has given his con
sent; he desires me to lose no time—I will bring him to pay you a visit—He rejoices in my choice—you shall have it out of his own mouth—name your hour, and he shall at
tend you—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Any time to-day—I shall stay at home on purpose—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: In the evening I will conduct him hither—in the mean time I feel an attachment here—The lady, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! you want to see my sister—I will send her to you, Sir, this instant—I beg your pardon for leaving you alone—ha! ha!—who could have thought of her making a conquest at last—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT
sp.p:
Sir, your most obedient—now, Clerimont, now your heart may rest content—your doubts and fears may all subside, and joy and rapture take their place—Miss Harlow shall be mine—she receives my vows; she approves my passion,— (sings and dances) Soft! here she comes—Her very appear
ance controuls my wildest hopes, and hushes my proud heart into respect and silent ad
miration—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, your servant—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I thought Mr. Harlow was here, Sir.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam, he is but just gone—how a single glance of her eye over-awes me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I wonder he would leave you alone, Sir—that is not so polite in his own house—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: How her modesty throws a veil over her inclinations!—my tongue faulters!—I can't speak to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: He seems in confusion—a pretty man too!—That this should be my sister's luck!—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I imagine you have been talking to him on the subject of the letter you sent this morning.—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam, I have presumed to—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Well! Sir, and he has no objection, I hope—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
She hopes! Heavens bless her for the word— (Aside.)—Madam, he has frankly consented, if his sister will do me that ho
nour—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: For his sister, I think I may venture to answer, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Generous! generous creature!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
You are sure, Sir, of Miss Harlow's ad
miration, and the whole family hold them
selves much obliged to you—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Madam, this extreme condescension has added rapture to the sentiments I felt before;
and it shall be the endeavour of my life to prove deserving of the amiable object I have dared to aspire to.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Sir, I make no doubt of your sincerity—I have already declared my sentiments—you know Mr. Harlow's—and if my sister is willing,—nothing will be wanting to con
clude this business—If no difficulties arise from her—for her temper is uncertain—as to my consent, Sir, your air, your manner have commanded it—Sir your most obe
dient—I'll send my sister to you—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Madam, (bowing) I shall endeavour to re
pay this goodness with excess of gratitude—Oh! she is an angel!—and yet, stupid that I am, I could not give vent to the tenderness I have within—it is ever so with sincere and generous love; it fills the heart with rap
ture, and then denies the power of uttering what we so exquisitely feel—Generous Miss Harlow! who could thus see thro' my con
fusion, interpret all appearances favourably, and with a dignity superior to her sex's lit
tle arts, forego the idle ceremonies of co
quetting, teazing, and tormenting her ad
mirer—I hear somebody.—Oh! here comes mistress Harlow—what a gloom sits upon her features!—She assumes authority here I find—but I'll endeavour by insinuation and res
pect—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: My sister has told me, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: He is a sweet figure.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
She rather looks like Miss Harlow's mo
ther than her sister-in-law—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
He seems abashed—his respect is the cause— (Aside)—My sister told me, Sir, that you was here—I beg pardon for mak
ing you wait so long—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh, ma'am (bows) the gloom disappears from her face, but the lines of ill-nature remain—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: I see he loves me by his confusion;—I'll cheer him with affability— (Aside)—Sir, the letter you was pleased to send, my sister has seen—and—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
And has assured me that she has no ob
jection—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: I am glad of that, Sir—I was afraid—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
No, ma'am, she has none—and Mr. Harlow, I have seen him too—he has ho
noured me with his consent—Now, ma
dam, the only doubt remains with you;—may I be permitted to hope—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, you appear like a gentleman,—and—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam, believe me, never was love more sincere, more justly founded on esteem, or kindled into higher admiration.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Sir, with the rest of the family I hold my
self much obliged to you, and—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Obliged!—'tis I that am obliged—there is no merit on my side—it is the conse
quence of impressions made upon my heart; and what heart can resist such beauty, such various graces!—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Sir, I am afraid—I wish my sister heard him (aside)—Sir, I am afraid you are la
vish of your praise; and the short date of your love, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
It will burn with unabating ardor—the same charms that first inspired it, will for ever cherish it, and add new fuel—But I
presume you hold this stile to try my since
rity—I see that's your aim—but could you read the feelings of my heart, you would not thus cruelly keep me in suspense.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Heavens! if my sister saw my power over him— (aside)—A little suspense cannot be deemed unreasonable—Marriage is an im
portant affair—an affair for life—and some caution you will allow necessary—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam!— (disconcerted)—oh! I dread the sourness of her look!—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: I can't help observing, Sir, that you dwell chiefly on articles of external and superficial merit; whereas the more valuable qualities of the mind, prudence, good sense, a well-regulated conduct—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am, I am not inattentive to those matters—oh! she has a notable household understanding, I warrant her— (aside)—but let me intreat you, madam, to do justice to my principles, and believe me a sincere, a generous lover—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Sir, I will frankly own that I have been trying you all this time, and from hence
forth all doubts are banished.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Your words recal me to new life—I shall for ever study to merit this goodness—But your fair sister—do you think I can depend upon her consent?—May I flatter myself she will not change her mind?—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
My sister cannot be insensible of the ho
nour you do us all—and, Sir, as far as I can act with propriety in the affair, I will en
deavour to keep them all inclined to favour you—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: You have an interest in my breast that will be busy for you—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: I am eternally devoted to you, madam—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: How modest, and yet how expressive he is!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Madam, I shall be for ever sensible of this extreme condescension, and shall think no pains too great to prove the gratitude and esteem I bear you—I beg my compliments to Mr. Harlow, and I shall be here with my uncle in the evening—as early as possible I shall come—my respects to your sister, ma'am
—and pray, madam, keep her in my in
terest—Madam, your most obedient—I have managed the motherly lady finely, I think (aside) Madam

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
What will my sister say now?—I shall hear no more of her taunts—A malicious thing!—I fancy she now sees that your giddy fli illegible ts are not always the highest beau
ties—Set her up, indeed!—Had she but heard him, the dear man!—what sweet things he said! and what sweet things he looked—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Well, sister!—how!—what does he say?—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Say, sister!—Every thing that is charm
ing—he is the prettiest man!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Well! I am glad of it—but all's well that ends well—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Envy, sister!—Envy, and downright malice!—Oh! had you heard all the tender things he uttered, and with that extasy too! that tenderness! that delight restrained by modesty!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I don't know tho'; there is something odd in it still—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! I don't doubt but you will say so—but you will find I have beauty enough left to make some noise in the world still—The men, sister, are the best judges of female beauty—Don't concern yourself about it, sister—Leave it all to them—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: But only think of a lover you never saw but once at Ranelagh—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Very true!—but even then I saw what work I made in his heart—Oh! I am in rap
tures with him, and he is in raptures with me— (Sings) Yes, I'll have a husband, ay! marry, &c.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: So, sister! how stand matters now?

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: As I could wish—I shall no more be a trouble to you—he has declared himself in the most warm and vehement manner—Tho' my sister has her doubts—she is a good friend—she is afraid of my success—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Pray, sister, don't think so meanly of me—I understand that sneer, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: And I understand you too, ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Come, come, I desire we may have no quarrelling—you two are always wrangling; but when you are separated, it is to be hoped you will then be more amicable. Things are now in a fair way—Tho', sister, let me tell you I am afraid our India friend will think himself ill treated.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: That's what I fear too—that's my reason for speaking—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! never throw away a thought on him.—Mr. Clerimont has my heart; and now I think I am settled for life—Sister, I love to plague her—now I think I am settled for life—for life,—for life, my dear sister—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Dinner is served, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Very well! come, sister, I give you joy—let us in to dinner.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! vulgar!—I can't eat—I must go and dress my head over again, and do a thousand things;—for I am determined I'll look this afternoon as well as ever I can.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Is not all this amazing, my dear?—her head is turned—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Well, let it all pass—don't you mind it—don't you say any thing—let her get mar
ried if she can—I am sure I shall rejoice at it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: And upon my word, my dear, so shall I—and if I interfere, it is purely out of friendship.—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
But be advised by me,—say no more to her.—If the affair goes on, we shall fairly get rid of her—Her peevish humours, and her maiden temper, are become insupporta
ble.—Come, let us in to dinner.—If Mr. Clerimont marries her, which indeed will be odd enough,—we shall then enjoy a little peace and quiet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: What in the world could the man see in her?—Oh! he will repent his bargain in a week or a fortnight; that I am sure he will—she is gone to dress now!—ha!ha!—Oh! how she rolls her pretty eyes in spite, And looks delightfully with all her might! Ha!ha! delightfully she will look indeed!

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter a Servant, and Capt. CAPE.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: YES, Sir, my master is at home—he has just done dinner, Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Very well then; tell him I would speak a word with him.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I beg pardon, Sir; I am but a stranger in the family—who shall I say?—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Capt. Cape, tell him—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: I can hardly believe my own eyes—s'death! I am almost inclined to think this letter, signed with Miss Harlow's name, a mere forgery by some enemy, to drive me into an excess of passion, and so injure us both—I don't know what to say to it—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Sir, I have waited on you about an extra
ordinary affair—I can't comprehend it, Sir—
Here is a letter with your sister's name—Look at it, Sir,—is that her hand-writing?—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I take it to be her writing—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: And do you know the contents?—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: I can't say I have read it—but—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: But you know the purport of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Partly.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: You do?—and is not it base treatment, Sir?—is it not unwarrantable?—can you justify her?

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: For my part, I leave women to manage their own affairs—I am not fond of inter-meddling—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: But, Sir—let me ask you,—Was not every thing agreed upon?—Are not the writings now in lawyers hands?—Was not next week fixed for our wedding?—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: I understood it so.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Very well then, and see how she treats me—She writes me here in a contemptuous
manner, that she recals her promise;—it was rashly given;—she has thought better of it; she will listen to me no more;—she is going to dispose of herself to a gentleman with whom she can be happy for life—and "I desire to see you no more, Sir"—There, that's free and easy, is not it?—What do you say to that?—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, it is not my affair—I have nothing to say to it.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Nothing to say to it!—Sir, I imagined I was dealing with people of honour.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: You have been dealing with a woman, and you know—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Yes, I know—I know the treachery of the sex—Who is this gentleman, pray?

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: His name is Clerimont—they have fixed the affair among themselves, and amongst them be it for me.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Very fine! mighty fine!—is Miss Har
low at home, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: She is; and here she comes too—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Very well!—let me hear it from herself, that's all—I desire to hear her speak for her
self—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
With all my heart.—I'll leave you toge
ther—you know, captain, I was never fond of being concerned in those things—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Capt. Cape, this is mighty odd—I thought, Sir, I desired—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Madam, I acknowledge the receipt of your letter, and, madam, the usage is so ex
traordinary, that I hold myself excusable if I refuse to comply with the terms you im
pose upon me.—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, I really wonder what you can mean—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Mistake me not, madam; I am not come to whimper or to whine, and to make a puppy of myself again—Madam that is all blown over.—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Well then, there is no harm done, and you will survive this I hope.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Survive it!—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Yes;—you won't grow desperate I hope—suppose you were to order somebody to take care of you, because you know fits of despair are sudden, and you may rashly do yourself a mischief—don't do any such thing, I beg you won't—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
This insult, madam!—Do myself a mis
chief!—Madam, don't flatter yourself that it is in your power to make me unhappy—it is not vexation brings me hither, I assure you—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Then let vexation take you away;—we were never designed for one another.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
My amazement brings me hither—amaze
ment that any woman can behave—but I don't want to upbraid—I only come to ask—for I can hardly as yet believe it—I only come to ask if I am to credit this pretty epistle?—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Every syllable—therefore take your an
swer, Sir, and truce with your importu
nity.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Very well, ma'am, very well—your humble servant, madam—I promise you, ma'am, I
can repay this scorn with scorn—with tenfold scorn, madam, such as this treatment de
serves—that's all—I say no more—your ser
vant ma'am—but let me ask you—is this a just return for all the attendance I have paid you these three years past?—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Perfectly just, Sir,—three years!—how could you be a dangler so long?—I told you what it would come to—can you think that raising a woman's expectation, and tiring her out of all patience, is the way to make sure of her at last?—you ought to have been a brisker lover, you ought indeed, Sir,—I am now contracted to another, and so there is an end of every thing between us.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Very well, madam,—and yet I can't bear to be despised by her—and can you, Miss Harlow, can you find it in your heart to treat me with this disdain?—have you no compassion?—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: No, positively none, Sir,—none—none—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Your own Capt. Cape,—whom you—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Whom I despise.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Whom you have so often encouraged to adore you.—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't touch my hand—I am now the property of another—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Can't you still break off with him?

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: No Sir, I can't; I won't; I love him, and Sir, if you are a man of honour, you will speak to me no more; desist, Sir, for if you don't, my brother shall tell you of it, Sir, and to-morrow Mr. Clerimont shall tell you of it.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Mr. Clerimont, madam, shall fight me, for daring—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: And must I fight you too, most noble, valiant captain?—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Laughed at too!—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
What a passion you are in!—I can't bear to see a man in such a passion—Oh! I have a happy riddance of you—the violence of your temper is dreadful—I won't stay a mo
ment longer with you—you frighten me—you have your answer,—and so your servant Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Ay! she is gone off like a fury, and the furies catch her, say I—I will never put up
with this—I will find out this Mr. Cleri
mont, and he shall be accountable to me—Mr. Harlow too shall be accountable to me.—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Mr. Harlow—I am used very ill here, Sir, by all of you, and Sir, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Nay; don't be angry with me, Sir,—I was not to marry you—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: But Sir, I can't help being angry—I must be angry—and let me tell you, you don't behave like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: How can Mr, Harlow help it, Sir, if my sister—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: You are too warm; you are indeed, Sir,—let us both talk this matter over a bottle—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: No, Sir—no bottle—over a cannon, if you will—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Mercy on me, Sir,—I beg you wont talk in that terrible manner—you frighten me, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Be you quiet, my dear,—Capt. Cape, I beg you will just step into that room with me; and if, in the dispatching one bottle, I don't acquit myself of all sinister dealing, why then—come, come, be a little mode
rate—you shall step with me—I'll take it as a favour—come, come, you must—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
I always found you a gentleman, Mr. Har
low, and so with all my heart,—I don't care if I do talk the matter over with you—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW
sp.p: Sir, I am obliged to you—I'll shew you the way—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: It is just as I foresaw—my sister was sure of him, and now is she going to break off for a young man that will despise her in a little time—I wish she would have Capt. Cape.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Is he gone, sister?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
No; and here is the deuce and all to do—he is for fighting every body—upon my word you are wrong—you don't behave gen
teelly in the affair.—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
Genteelly!—I like that notion prodigi
ously—an't I going to marry genteelly?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Well, follow your own inclinations—I won't intermeddle any more, I promise you—I'll step into the parlour, and see what they are about.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: As you please, ma'am—I see plainly the ill-natured thing can't bear my success—Heavens! here comes Mr. Clerimont—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: You are earlier than I expected, Sir.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
I have flown, madam, upon the wings of love—I have seen my uncle, and he will be here within this half hour—every thing suc
ceeds to my wishes with him—I hope there is no alteration here, madam, since I saw you—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Nothing that signifies, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: You alarm me—Mr. Harlow has not changed his mind, I hope.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: No, Sir—he continues in the same mind.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: And your sister—I tremble with doubt and fear—she does not surely recede from the sentiments she flattered me with.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Why there, indeed, I can't say much—she—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: She—I don't know what to make of her—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh! I am on the rack—in pity, do not torture me—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: How tremblingly solicitous he is—Oh! I have made a sure conquest (aside.)—Why, she, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Ay,—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: She does not seem entirely to approve—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: You kill me with despair—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! he is deeply smitten, (aside)—She thinks another match would suit better—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Another match!

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, another; an India captain, who has made his proposals; but I shall take care to see him dismissed.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
I promise you I will—tho' he runs much in my sister's head, and she has taken pains to bring my other relations over to her opi
nion.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Oh! cruel, cruel!—I could not have ex
pected that from her—but has she fixed her heart upon a match with this other gentle
man?

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Why, truly I think she has—but my will in this affair must be, and shall be consulted.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
And so it ought, ma'am—your long ac
quaintance with the world, madam—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Long acquaintance, Sir! I have but a few years experience only—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
That is, your good sense, ma'am—oh! con
found my tongue! how that slipt from me (aside)—your good sense,—your early good sense,—and—and—inclination should be con
sulted.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
And they shall, Sir—hark!—I hear her—I'll tell you what—I'll leave you this oppor
tunity to speak to her once more, and try to win her over by persuasion—It will make things easy if you can—I am gone, Sir.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
The happiness of my life will be owing to you, Madam.—The woman is really bet
ter natured than I thought she was—she comes, the lovely tyrant comes—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: She triumphs in her cruelty, and I am ruined—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
You seem afflicted, Sir—I hope no mis
fortune—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: The severest misfortune!—you have broke my heart—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I break your heart, Sir?—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Yes, cruel fair—you,—you have undone me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: You amaze me, Sir, pray how can I—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
And you can seem unconscious of the mis
chief you have made—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Pray unriddle, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam, your sister has told me all—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Ha! ha! what has she told you, Sir?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: It may be sport to you—but to me 'tis death—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: What is death?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: The gentleman from India, madam—I have heard it all—you can give him a preference—you can blast my hopes—my fond delighted hopes, which you yourself had cherished.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: The gentleman is a very good sort of man.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Oh! she loves him, I see— (aside)—Ma
dam, I perceive my doom is fixed, and fixed by you—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: How have I fixed your doom?—if I speak favourably of captain Cape,—he deserves it, Sir.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh! heavens! I cannot bear this—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I believe there is nobody that knows the gentleman, but will give him his due praise—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Love! love! love!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: And besides, his claim is in fact prior to yours.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
And must love be governed, like the bu
siness of mechanics, by the laws of tyrant custom?—Can you think so, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you know I am not in love.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh! cruel!—no, madam, I see you are not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: And really now, Sir, reasonably speaking, my sister is for treating captain Cape very ill—He has been dancing attendance here these three years—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Yet that you know, when you were pleased to fan the rising flame, that matchless beauty had kindled in my heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Matchless beauty!—ha! ha!—I cannot but laugh at that—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Laugh, madam, if you will at the pangs you yourself occasion—yes, triumph, if you will—I am resigned to my fate, since you will have it so—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
I have it so!—you seem to frighten your
self without cause,—If I speak favourably of any body else, Sir,—what then?—I am not to marry him, you know.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: An't you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I!—no, truly—thank heaven!—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: She revives me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: That must be as my sister pleases.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Must it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Must it?—to be sure it must?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: And may I hope some interest in your heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: My heart, Sir!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
While it is divided, while another has pos
session of but part of it.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I don't understand him!—Why, it has been given away long ago.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: I pray you do not tyrannize me thus with alternate doubts and fears—if you will but bless me with the least kind return—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Kind return! what, would you have me fall in love with you?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: It will be generous to him who adores you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Adore me!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Even to idolatry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: What can he mean?—I thought my sister was the object of your adoration.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Your sister, ma'am! I shall ever respect her as my friend on this occasion, but love—no—no—she is no object for that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: She may have been handsome in her time,—but that has been all over long ago—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Well! this is charming—I wish she heard him now, with her new-fangled airs, (aside.)—But let me understand you, Sir—adore me!—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: You!—you!—and only you!—by this fair hand—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Hold, hold—this is going too far—but pray, Sir, have you really conceived a pas
sion for me?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
You know I have—a passion of the ten
derest nature.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: And was that your drift in coming hither?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: What else could induce me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: And introduced yourself here, to have an opportunity of speaking to me?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: My angel! don't torment me thus—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Angel! and pray, Sir, what do you sup
pose Mr. Harlow will say to this?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh! ma'am—he! he approves my passion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Does he really?—I must speak to him about that—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Do so, ma'am, you will find I am a man of more honour than to deceive you—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Well! it will be whimsical if he does—and my sister too, this will be a charming discovery for her, (aside.)—Ha! ha! well! really Sir, this is mighty odd—I'll speak to Mr. Harlow about this matter this very moment—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Oh! you will find it all true—and may I then flatter myself—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Oh! to be sure—such an honourable pro
ject—I'll step to him this moment—and then, sister, I shall make such a piece of work for you—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Very well, ma'am—see Mr. Harlow im
mediately—he will confirm it to you—while there is life there is hope—such matchless beauty!—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir, for leaving you all this time—Well, what says my sister?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: She has given me some glimmering hopes.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Well, don't be uneasy about her—it shall be as I please—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
But with her own free consent it would be better—however, to you I am bound by eve
ry tie, and thus let me seal a vow—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p:
He certainly is a very passionate lover—Lord! he is ready to eat my hand up with kisses—I wish my sister saw this— (aside.)—Hush! I hear Capt. Cape's voice—the hi
deous Tramontane!—he is coming this way—I would not see him again for the world—I'll withdraw a moment, Sir—you'll excuse
me—Mr. Clerimont— (kisses her hand and curtsies very low) your servant Sir—Oh! he is a charming man.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
There she goes, the perfidious! Sir, I un
derstand your name is Clerimont—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: At your service, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Then, Sir, draw this moment.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Draw, Sir! for what?

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: No evasion, Sir.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Explain the cause.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
The cause is too plain—your making love to that lady who went out there this mo
ment—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: That lady! not I, upon my honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: No shuffling, Sir—draw—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Sir, I can repel an injury like this—but your quarrel is groundless,—and, Sir, if ever I made love to that lady, I will lay my bo
som naked to your sword,—That lady!—I resign all manner of pretension to her—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: You resign her, Sir.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Entirely.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Then I am pacified—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I never so much as thought of the lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
So, Sir—fine doings you have been car
rying on here—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: You have been attempting my wife, I find—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mr Harlow—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: You have behaved in a very base manner, and I insist upon satisfaction; draw, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: This is the strangest accident!—I assure you, Sir,—only give me leave—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: I will not give you leave—I insist—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, Mr. Harlow—this is neither time or place—and besides, hear the gentle
man; I have been over-hasty, and he has satisfied me—only hear him—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Sir, I will believe my own wife—come on, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
I assure you, Mr. Harlow, I came into this house upon honourable principles—in
duced, Sir, by my regard for Miss Harlow—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: For Miss Harlow!—zoons, draw—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Again!—this is downright madness—two upon me at once—you will murder me be
tween you—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: There is one too many upon him, sure enough,—and so, captain, put up—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Resign your pretensions to Miss Harlow—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Resign Miss Harlow!—not for the uni
verse—in her cause I can be as ready as any bravo of ye all—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
For heaven's sake, Capt. Cape—do mode
rate your anger—this is neither time or place—I have been too rash myself—I beg you will be pacified— (He puts up.)—Mr. Clerimont, sheath your sword—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: I obey, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Capt. Cape. how can you?—you promised me you would let things take their course?—if my sister will marry the gentleman, how is he to blame?—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—I have done—she is a worthless woman—that's all—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: A worthless woman, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Ay! worthless—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Damnation!—Draw, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Mr. Clerimont, you are too warm—and there's a gentleman coming—this is your uncle, I suppose—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: It is—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW
sp.p:
I'll wave all disputes now, that I may con
clude my sister's marriage.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Mr. Heartwell, Sir—Mr. Harlow, Sir.—

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p: My nephew has informed me, Sir, of the honour you have done him, and I am come to give my consent.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
I thought it necessary, Sir, to have the ad
vice of Mr. Clerimont's friends, as he is very young, and my sister not very handsome.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: She is an angel, Sir—

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p:
Patience, Charles, patience.—My ne
phew's estate will provide for his eldest born, and upon the younger branches of his mar
riage I mean to settle my fortune.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Generously spoken, Sir, and so there is no occasion for delay—who waits there?—tell the ladies they are wanting—

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p: I have ever loved my nephew, and since he tells me he has made a good choice, I shall be glad to see him happy.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: But, Sir, let me tell you, that your nephew has used me very basely, and Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Nay, nay, captain,—this is wrong now; every thing was settled between us in the other room—recollect yourself—do, I beg you will—Oh! here come the ladies.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Now, sister, you shall see I have completed my conquest—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Now then I am happy indeed—my lovely, charming bride—thus let me snatch you to my heart, and thus, and thus—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Zoons! before my face—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Prithee, indulge my transport—my life, my angel!—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: I desire you will desist, Sir—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, prithee be quiet—my charm
ing, charming wife!—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: That lady is not your wife—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: How my wife,—not my wife!—extasy and bliss!—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir—this is too much—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Ha! ha! you are very pleasant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Zoons! Sir, no trifling—that lady is my wife—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: I say, Sir, that lady is my wife!

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! I see through this—it is a co
medy of errors, I believe—

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p: What does all this mean?

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Your wife, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, my wife—and there is my sister, if you please to take her—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p:
Sir, this is the lady whom you have de
sired in marriage.

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Who I, Sir?—I beg your pardon—that lady I took to be your wife (pointing to Miss Harlow,)—and that lady (pointing to Mrs. Harlow) I took to be your sister—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE. and Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Lord! lord! have I been made a fool of all this time!—furies! torture! murder!—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—my lady fair is taken in, I think—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Sister, the men don't see with my eyes—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! the gentleman is no dangler, ma'am.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: This is a complete conquest my sister has made—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: I can't bear this—Sir, I desire I may not be made a jest of—did not you sollicit me?—importune me?—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
For your interest in that lady, ma'am,—whom I took for Miss Harlow—I beg your
pardon if I am mistaken,—I hope there is no harm done.—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but there is harm done—I am made sport of—exposed to derision—Oh! I cannot bear this—I cannot bear it—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Don't cry, sister—some faces preserve the bloom longer than others you know—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p: Loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p: I don't understand all this—is that lady your wife, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: She is, Sir.

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p: And pray, nephew—you took that lady for Mr. Harlow's sister, I suppose—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: I did, Sir.—I beg pardon for the trouble I have given—I am in such confusion, I can hardly—

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p: Well, well! the thing is cleared up, and there is no harm done—but you should have known what ground you went upon—ha! ha! I can't help laughing neither—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Why faith, nor I—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p:
Since matters have turned so unexpected
ly, I beg pardon for my mistake, and Sir, I take my leave—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: And will you treat me in this manner, Sir? will you draw me into such a scrape, and not—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Ma'am, that gentleman would cut my throat—his claim is prior to mine—and, I dare say, he will be very glad to be reconciled, madam.

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: You are a base man then, and I reject you—Capt. Cape I see my error, Sir, and I resign myself to you.

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
No, madam, I beg to be excused—I have been a dangler too long—I ought to have been a brisker lover—I shall endeavour to survive it, ma'am—I won't do myself a mis
chief—and I have my answer—I am off, madam—loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I told you this, my dear sister—

sp.speaker: CLERIMONT.
sp.p: Madam, I dare say the gentleman will think better of it—Mr. Harlow, I am sorry for all this confusion, and I beg pardon of the whole company for my mistake—Mrs. Harlow, I wish you all happiness, ma'am—angelic creature!—what a misfortune to lose her!—

sp.speaker: Capt. CAPE.
sp.p:
And I will follow his example—Miss Har
low I wish you all happiness,—angelic crea
ture! what a misfortune to lose her!—upon my soul I think you a most admirable illegible , and so now you may go, and bewail your virgi
nity in the mountains—loll toll loll—

sp.speaker: Miss HARLOW.
sp.p: Oh! oh! I can't bear to be treated in this manner—I'll go and hide myself from the world for ever—Oh! oh!—the men are all savages, barbarians, monsters, and I hate the whole sex—Oh! oh!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: My dear sister, with her beauty and her conquests, ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: Ha! ha! very whimsical and ridiculous—

sp.speaker: HEARTWELL.
sp.p: Sir, my nephew is young—I am sorry for this scene of errors, and I hope you will ascribe the whole to his inexperience—

sp.speaker: Mr. HARLOW.
sp.p: I certainly shall, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARLOW.
sp.p: I cautioned my sister sufficiently about this matter, but vanity got the better of her, and leaves her now a whimsical instance of folly and affectation.
sp.l: In vain the FADED TOAST her mirror tries,
And counts the cruel murders of her eyes;
For ridicule, fly-peeping o'er her head,
Will point the roses and the lillies dead;
And while, fond soul! she weaves her myrtle chain,
She proves a subject of the comic strain.
